user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo(osal_id_t sem_id, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *bin_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(bin_prop);

    memset(bin_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_bin_sem_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_bin_sem_table, token);

        strncpy(bin_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(bin_prop->name) - 1);
        bin_prop->creator = record->creator;
        return_code       = OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(&token, bin_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BinSemGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_bin_sem_table
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    int32     value;
} OS_bin_sem_prop_t
...
int32 OS_BinSemGetInfo_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_bin_sem_prop_t *sem_prop)
{
    OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t *sem;

    sem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_bin_sem_table, *token);

    /* put the info into the structure */
    sem_prop->value = sem->current_value;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining code fragments are necessary for correct operation and are not candidates for dead-code under MISRA C Rule 2.2: - The call that looks up and locks the object (OS_ObjectIdGetById(...)) is required to validate the id and obtain a token; removing it would change behavior. - Access of the global tables via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and reading record->creator (bin_prop->creator = record->creator;) directly provide the API outputs and are effective operations. - OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token) finishes the object transaction (unlock/release) and cannot be removed without changing program semantics. - The final return of return_code and the local variable declarations are used to convey and hold the function result and are not dead. These operations have observable effects (resource management, outputs, return status) and therefore do not meet the definition of dead code.
